beats.text_on_screen: Black Forest Gravel | Freiburg, Black Forest, Germany | 65 mi
beats.editing_note: Let the course breathe. Show the route map, then cut to terrain-specific B-roll. This is the SETUP phase — grounding the viewer before the data analysis. Pacing: 25-40 sec cuts.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Top 8
beats.narration: Time to break down the scorecard. Logistics. 3 out of 5. Adequate. The word was invented for this. Freiburg location offers solid transportation infrastructure and tourism support, though specific race-day logistics remain unclear. Length. 3 out of 5. The Goldilocks zone of suffering. 65 miles hits the gravel sweet spot - long enough to hurt, short enough to survive poor pacing decisions. Elevation. 3 out of 5. Enough vertical to remind you gravity exists. 4500 feet over 65 miles means consistent climbing through "the most beautiful peaks in the Black Forest" without Alpine suffering. Climate. 3 out of 5. The weather could go either way. Historical weather data shows average highs of 75°F and lows of 56°F, with a 51% chance of rain on any given day. Adventure. 3 out of 5. This race takes you somewhere different. The Black Forest delivers backcountry mystique through "Lange Schotter Alleen" (long gravel avenues) with "no cell service" reported by riders. Experience. 3 out of 5. You'll remember this one. Mostly fondly. The Black Forest delivers adventure through Dreisamtal with riders praising "breathtaking views of rural terrain" and wildlife encounters. Community. 3 out of 5. Community is a real selling point. Value. 3 out of 5. The math works out. Barely. €70 entry fee includes all food and drink at GenussHotSpots throughout the route, offering "Black Forest tapas, barista coffee, ice cream, and Rothaus beer.
beats.editing_note: PROGRESSIVE RHYTHM: start tight (15-20 sec per dimension), slow down for the most interesting scores (30-40 sec). Each score: number appears, brief pause, explanation. Avatar reacts to extreme scores (5/5 = chef_kiss, 1/5 = facepalm). RE-ENGAGEMENT at 3:00 mark: insert a surprising score reveal or a meme reaction to break the pattern.
